Image 11 of 11 Fortune names the most powerful women in business 1 / 11 Back to Gallery gallery_thumbs_close|article-gallery-6498942|article-gallery-6498942|0 gallery_overlay_close|article-gallery-6498942|article-gallery-6498942|0 Fortune on Thursday revealed its " Most Powerful Women " in business 2015 list, which includes 51 women from business, technology and entertainment. Twenty-seven of them are CEOs.
Mary Bara, CEO of General Motors, took the top spot on the list. Meg Whitman, CEO, chairman and president of Hewlett-Packard, is the highest ranked Bay Area leader, coming it at 7th. This is a small dip since last year, when she ranked 6th. In 2014, HP had about $111.5 billion in revenues and $5 billion in profits.
Click through the slides above to see who else made it into the top 10.
The Bay Area is also represented by Facebook's Sheryl Sandberg (8th), Oracle's Safra Catz (12th), Apple's Angela Ahrendts (16th), Yahoo's Marissa Mayer (18th), YouTube's Susan Wojcicki (19th), Google's Ruth Porat (26th), Wells Fargo's Carrie Tolstedt (27th) and Intel's Diane Bryant (43rd).
There are 12 newcomers on this year's list, including musician Taylor Swift, who's also the youngest person on Fortune's list at age 25. Mayer is the second youngest, at age 40.
The 27 CEOs on the Fortune's "Most Powerful Women" list -- the most it's ever had -- control $1 trillion in stock market value, according to Fortune. The company considers four criteria in its ranking: the size and importance of the woman's business in the global economy, the health and direction of the business, the arc of the women's career and their social and cultural influence. Carly Fiorina took the top spot on Fortune's first-ever "Most Powerful Women" list in 1998.
